general.purpose: Universal Design for Learning (UDL) supports learning for all by offering multiple means of engagement, representation, and expression.
strategies: Offer information in text, audio, visuals, and interactive formats.
Provide scaffolds and self-monitoring opportunities.
Allow learners to demonstrate understanding in various modalities (oral, written, visual, video).

adhd.target_group: Attention and Executive Function challenges (e.g. ADHD)
strategies: Break tasks into short, sequential “chunks” with clear start and stop (“chunking”).
Use timers, visual countdowns, or progress bars to manage attention.
Embed student interests or examples to increase motivation.
Offer task-response choice (e.g., oral vs. written vs. visual).
Include self-check questions or micro-reflection after each segment.
adhd.source: Universal Design for Learning research tailored for ADHD and Executive Function support

strategies: Provide audio- or screen‑reader versions of text.
Use large, sans-serif fonts with ample spacing.
Allow oral responses instead of written when possible.
Give phonetic or visual cues with vocabulary.
Focus feedback on content over mechanics.
dyslexia.source: Dyslexia‑specific UDL strategies from dyslexia research

strategies: Use visual schedules, icons, and graphic organizers for structure.
Pre‑announce transitions and maintain predictable routines.
Incorporate student-specific interests into learning examples.
Allow non-verbal or artistic expression (drawing, comics) over extended writing.
Use social narratives or scripts to explain classroom routines.
autism.source: UDL research applying to autism‑specific learning needs

strategies: Use the Concrete‑Representational‑Abstract (CRA) sequence.
Visualize math concepts with manipulatives, number lines, or area models.
Keep problem steps minimal—break into parts.
Offer math glossaries and reference sheets.
Let students explain reasoning orally or visually before writing.
dyscalculia.source: Evidence-based CRA research for math difficulties

strategies: Permit speech-to-text or typing instead of handwriting.
Provide graphic organizers or mind‑maps before writing.
Use wide‑ruled or raised‑line paper and ergonomic writing tools.
Give clear, step‑by‑step rubrics and writing checkpoints.
Allow students to “think storm” or present ideas orally/visually first.
Offer checklists and planning templates (e.g. project maps, calendars).
Provide guided goal‑setting and progress‑tracking tools.
Embed prompts to ‘stop and think’ before moving on.
Model task breakdown and process explicitly before independent work.
Include regular self-reflection or peer-feedback pauses.
executive_function.source: Instructional design using UDL principles to build executive functioning

Provide cognate awareness activities (e.g. hospital, hospital).
Include culturally relevant examples and background.
